author: @JasonTVification
text: If anyone is trying to do this on Mac Catalina, they have switched from using bash shell to ZSH. This means instead of using nano to edit .bash_profile, you should edit .zshrc instead. Everything else should be the same. Only took me 2 hours to figure this out.

author: @lelelucci
text: If you set your terminal to use zsh (Catalina default shell) remember that the new equivalent to ~/.bash_profile is ~/.zshrc (for setting your aliases) and ~/.zshenv (for customizing your PATH).  se more here: http://zsh.sourceforge.net/Intro/intro_3.html

author: @FRIENDSofCAP
text: FYI:  You don't actually have to restart the terminal in order for .bash_profile edits to take effect...  All ou do is the following: type 'source .bash_profile' and it will refresh the .bash_prifile in the system.

author: @question3v3ryth1ng5
text: I am confused about one small thing. When you nano into .bash_profile and add "Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.7/bin" to the beginning of your $PATH, why exactly are you adding that dir? Is that simply where you installed your python 3.7 to? So if I installed my python 3 version to "usr/bin/python3" would I simply replace the directory you used in your instance? For example for me would I just PATH="/usr/bin:${PATH}" ? Just a little confused as to what directory you are actually putting in front of your $PATH, I guess. I am probably over-complicating it needlessly, but I just really want to make sure I understand this going forward.    Of course I wouldn't actually add the PATH="/usr/bin:${PATH}" since that directory is already in my $PATH by default. I am just trying to make sure I am understanding the concept of what adding the directory to the path that you did, will do exactly and why you chose that particular directory. So please let me know if I am thinking of this concept correctly or if I completely missed the mark. Huge thanks for this series, though. I am really learning a lot.

author: @lazymouse636
text: Your explanation of the export command in the .bash_profile is not correct.... If you set an environment variable that variable is only known in that shell. The export command makes sure that the environment variable you set in your current shell is passed to new shell/commands you start. you don't need a seperate export command you can  export VAR=value in one line.
